issues.text: whether an item of Rs. 42,63,090-14-7 should have been allowed as a trading loss in computing the profits of the appellant-company under S. 3 of the Indore Industrial Tax Rules, 1927

holdings.text: We cannot allow a question which at its best is a mixed question of fact and law to be raised for the first time before us.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot allow a question which at its best is a mixed question of fact and law to be raised for the first time before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contention not advanced in prior proceedings; mixed question of fact and law; assessee deprived of opportunity to lead evidence.

holdings.text: We shall proceed with the appeal on the basis that for the purpose of deducting trading losses in computing trading profits there is no difference between the Income-tax Act and the relevant Indore Industrial Tax Rules.

anchor.surface_text: We shall proceed with the appeal on the basis that for the purpose of deducting trading losses in computing trading profits there is no difference between the Income-tax Act and the relevant Indore Industrial Tax Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumption made to proceed after rejecting new contention; no opinion expressed on merits.

holdings.text: the said debt which had become irrecoverable was a trading loss deductible in computing the profit of the appellant-company in the assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, find no difficulty in holding that the said debt which had become irrecoverable was a trading loss deductible in computing the profit of the appellant-company in the assessment year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debt arose from powers conferred by MoA, resolutions, agency agreement; utilised per practice; GBM approved accounts; irrecoverable due to liquidation; proper debit/credit in trading accounts per commercial practice.

holdings.text: It was a loss incidental to the appellants business and is certainly sanctioned by commercial practice and trading principles.

anchor.surface_text: It was a loss incidental to the appellants business and is certainly sanctioned by commercial practice and trading principles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfies Badridas Daga test: arises from carrying on business via authorised agents; analogous to agent misappropriation and dacoity loss in precedents.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that the High Court went wrong in holding that the said amount represented loss incurred by the appellant dehors its business.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the High Court went wrong in holding that the said amount represented loss incurred by the appellant dehors its business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loss not dehors business but incidental; reverses lower courts' findings on non-business nature despite agents' conduct.

holdings.text: In the result, the appeal is allowed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of holdings on deductibility of trading loss.

precedents.citation: Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 [1959 S.C.R. 690, 695]

anchor.surface_text: The relevant principle of law has been laid down by this Court in Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 . There, after companysidering the relevant decisions on the subject, this Court laid down the following test The result is that when a claim is made for a deduction for which there is nospecific provision in S. 10 2 , whether it is admissible or number will depend on whether, having regard to accepted companymercial practice and trading principles, it can be said to arise out of the carrying on of the business and to be incidental

precedents.case_name: Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: when a claim is made for a deduction for which there is nospecific provision in S. 10 2 , whether it is admissible or number will depend on whether, having regard to accepted companymercial practice and trading principles, it can be said to arise out of the carrying on of the business and to be incidental to it
precedents.cited_holding: the amount misappropriated and found irrecoverable was an allowable deduction under the Income-tax Act

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. M s. Nainital Bank Ltd. 1 [1965 1 S.C.R. 340]

anchor.surface_text: In a recent decision in The Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. M s. Nainital Bank Ltd.  1  this Court held that an amount lost to the bank by dacoity was a loss incidental to the business of banking. There, in the companyrse of the business large amounts were, kept in the bank premises, and this Court held that the risk of loss by dacoity was incidental to a banking business. If that be so, the fact that the Managing Agents brought into the companypanys till larger amounts than the companypanys business demanded at a particular point of time would number make the borrowings or the lending of money to themselves any the less incidental to the sanctioned business operations.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. M s. Nainital Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: an amount lost to the bank by dacoity was a loss incidental to the business of banking

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the High Court went wrong in holding that the said amount represented loss incurred by the appellant dehors its business. In the result, the appeal is allowed.
